ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Very appreciated perspective from a practitioner

Larry knows a LOT about the subject. He's a bit new to teaching, but his concern for student's learningis evident. Fewer text on the slides would help. Guest speakers were great and helped to break it up. Class was more engaging the more interactive it was.

This course was excellent!! I am so grateful to have Mr. Reilly teach for us here and appreciate the administrations effort to meet student energy demands. This is a spectacular addition to the energy course selections. In addition, I find it refreshing to have a experienced professional from the electric utilities sector share his experiences in an unbiased and critical manner. I appreciated his candidness and interest in thoughtful discussion about the future of electric utilities. I would take this course again and again.

Overall, I think Larry did very well considering this was his first time teaching the course. The material covered in this course is desperately needed at FES and Larry is the perfect guy for the job. He has a ton of experience in the electric utilities industry and his insights are top notch. He brought in some excellent guest speakers which really added to the value of the course.

Very valuable course, and I think Larry has a lot of potential, but sometimes it felt like we moved/glossed over a lot of fine print very quickly that no one but a few people who had interned or worked in the electric industry understood. Thankfully my peers could answer questions, and Larry was welcoming too.

There were no field trips, though it could be interesting to take a Friday visit to ISO-NE in Holyoke, MA.Larry was fantastic overall. He is extremely knowledgeable and articulate. I, and others, spoke of how great it was to have a utility executive teaching the course.He brought in some interesting speakers too.
I really enjoyed the class.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Course materialsHaving slides to refer back toGreat guest speakers

Larry is a wealth of knowledge. To understand where the energy system is going, we need to know where it's been. Larry has been there and done that for electric utilities his entire career. His lectures were helpful, but the Q&A we did every session was even better.The homeworks were generally very helpful and forced us to dig into the issues.I also appreciated that Larry brought in guest speakers. Based on the feedback Larry collected in class, I think guest speakers will be even better next year.
Practitioner's perspectiveLecturer was responsive to student questions and interests, both in and out of the classroomTight presentation of material in powerpoint decks
The fact that it exists. This is a space a lot of energy people at FES want to enter, and this course allowed us to get a better sense of the industry.

Excellent content that had both breadth and depth.Experienced professional *with a strong a genuine interest* in teaching his studentsHe appreciated the opportunity to teach at Yale and is committed to that purpose.challenging homeworksexcellent reading and supplemental materialVERY organized
Cleared up a lot of difficulty I had understanding the ratemaking process. Really glad the course covered that

Professor Reilly was incredibly knowledgeable and shared a lot of personal industry experience. The other students and Matthew were very helpful in contributing to the discussion, drawing on personal experiences to comment on speakers. The speakers were also a great part of the course.
Larry has great industry experience and can organize a classroom well.He makes a dry subject interesting.

Larry's experience in the field, topics covered, and guest speakers. It was also great getting all of the FES energy nerds into one room. Loved the people in this class and the discussions in class were excellent.
The guest speakers were excellent! Larry's real-world experience and ability to bring in examples from his professional life was great.
The subject matter. Very very useful for the energy people here at FES.
Learning about a topic of immense interest that had not been offered elsewhere at Yale before Larry arrived.

The assignments were all different prompted me to think differently each time. Responses required strategic thinking and role play.The division of course grade between the assignment and final project worked wonderfully because the course load was spread evenly through the semester. Also the course got over earlier than others, which was great too, because it reduced stress towards the end.
Great insider's view of the utility industry.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Pace -- too fast for non-expert energists.
I think Larry will get a little more comfortable with lecturing as he gets more practice at it.
More detail on rate making contentMaybe a speaker or two less?

I think the course needs a better framework. As-is, it feels a bit like a description of all the different aspects of the industry. Which is fine, but it would be better if he could put them in a larger context. How does the electric utility compare to other regulated utilities? What is the future? Just zoom, provide a framework that helps us to understand generally how these various things fit together. More towards theory.

there are no aspects I feel need particular improvement. This was a great first run.further thought could be put into who is invited to guest speak, and some lecture segments could be replaced with either different topics or further depth into topics we covered.

Sometimes the classes were a bit of information overload. The slides were all very busy, which is a good thing if we want to go back and reference them in the future, but difficult to manage when actively in class.

At times the 3 hour class could seem very long. There was also not a lot of opportunity to see how I was doing in the class, and it was hard as an undergraduate to feel like I could match the experience that some of the graduate students brought to the table. I feel like I would have benefited from an exam to show that I had mastered the material, as the problem sets were out of limited points and it was very easy to do poorly on them by missing a question or two.
Sometimes lectures dragged on.
I think Larry's lecture structure, timing, and delivery could use some work. However, it was his first time teaching so I can't blame him too much for that.
The homework needs to be better tied to the course material
The grading on the final project felt a little unfair...like Larry only gave us credit for the parts of our paper that he had prior experience with and thus felt able to assess.

Probably the lecture delivery. Powerpoints were nice but I felt like we could have taken out a couple lectures and focused on the less obvious things (e.g. rate making, PUCs), and gone a little more slowly over those.
Probably some earlier deadlines on the term project to ensure groups are making progress.
Need more focus on tools to analyze different problems facing utilities. Sometimes it seemed like we were just going down a huge list of bullet points.
Make the slides more interesting. If possible, break into 2 lectures per week. 3 hours of monotonous slides is tough to process.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
NA

Lectures were interactive. Larry was adept at covering both details and high level policy... and when he didn't know the answer, he acknowledged that and got an answer. Some people prefer to pretend as though they know all. Larry is nothing like that... and that's important.
NA

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course is essential for anyone who wants to work on energy issues in the US. It's likely very helpful for folks working on energy issues abroad, though each electricity system is likely unique in some ways.
Directly applicable knowledge for the industry I will be working. I better understand its evolution, especially from a regulatory angle, and who the respective stakeholders are.

It is central to my program. To enter the energy profession it is essential to have an understanding of how the electric utility industry functions, flaws and opportunity for transform the business model.**** WE NEED MORE ENERGY CLASSES LIKE THIS AT FES****
This course is really important for people coming to F&ES for energy. It's a great followup to the ESA course, as it brings his high-level topics down to earth and practicality.
I'm interested in how utilities can solve many of the problems facing countries on the energy front, and am majoring in Economics and Environmental Studies.

I'm interested in utility-scale energy efficiency programs and this was the perfect class to round out my experience at Yale. It is critical to understand the inner-workings of the utility industry to enact change in the energy sector. This class provides that.
Understanding utilities and the regulatory systems in which they live is essential if you want to work in energy!
Energy class for an energy person
My studies are focused on energy. Understanding monopolistic utilities is critical in expediting the world's transition to a competitive market place for energy.

A must for students in interested in Energy. The course gives a great overview of the state, working and transition of utilities, although the focus may be on the USA. This course and the Political Economy of Global Energy Policy complement each other really well.
This course fits really well for people focusing on energy, particularly on demand side management.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It filled a critical gap in the FES energy curriculum
Career preparation.
my response is above.
See my answer to #17.
I'm interested in how utilities can solve many of the problems facing countries on the energy front, and am majoring in Economics and Environmental Studies.
Total no-brainer for me. I'm an energy efficiency geek and want to work for/with utilities in my career.
I was so excited to have a very practical energy class added to the curriculum, and to learn form a practitioner.
Didn't know anything about the electric utility space
It sounded as though it would be the most interesting course offered at Yale.
I was interested in all courses on Energy.
Because I am interested in the electric utility industry.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes, exceeded my expectations
Yes. I would have appreciated more understanding of how to analyze wholesale power markets and how to value power assets.
Yes. The problem sets were very good. The second one - the excel one on rates - needs improvement, but we discussed that in class.
YES.

Yes, especially the first half of the course. I really enjoyed reading and writing about the utility issues, and thinking about the TOU rate assignment. The second half of the course was a bit redundant for me as a 2nd-year, 2nd semester student, but I think it probably was useful for 1st years who had not encountered that as much before.
Mostly, yes.
Yes. Great course.
Yes.
yes
I think so. I wasn't sure what to expect and I sure learned a lot.
They exceeded expectations.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: By work group, I'm assuming our group for the end of year project. The advantage was that we got to dig into a topic in much greater depth.
Learning from different members' experience and skill-sets. Covered more ground/material than possible if working alone and practice collaboration skills.

Definitely keep the group work. Students in the class mostly know eachother, and working together on a pitch is a good fit for our interests. Enjoyed the collegial atmosphere of the final presentation day.
I should have worked in a group for the first two homework assignments. they were challenging and I should have recognized the need to get help from the TA or meet with friends.

Advantages are that we were able to accomplish a pretty detailed project in a short period of time. Five heads are better than one.Disadvantages are that it's always difficult to coordinate meeting times. Also, the quality of the final product depends heavily on people's commitment. It's tricky to coordinate input from five different people for a paper, and have the paper appear professional.But, in the end that's a life skill we'll all have to deal with in the real world anyways. So it's a good thing to practice now.Overall, I think the pros of groupwork definitely outweigh the cons.

Hard to know exactly what aspects of our group presentation were being graded. One advantage was that people had very different skill sets, but at the same time this made certain sections of the project very siloed.
I enjoyed the final group project a lot.
we learned from each other. definitely beneficial
Plus: working with an array of people who had very different skills sets and bringing it all to the table.Minus: having to put it all together
Multiple skills (financial modeling, as well as climate, technology, legal&regulatory understandings) were brought to the table and made the term project much more cohesive.
Disadvantges were that the group can have people who don't contribute much.
Meeting very engaging people from different schools.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Based on technical, insiders knowledge of the electric utilities industry. Fast-paced and detailed, but very interesting. Good prep for the real world
If you care about energy, take the course.
Take it and do the reading! Larry is very generous with his time!

If you're interested in energy they should take the course. If they are new to the material or have a busy schedule they should definitely consider working in a group or make time to see the TA. If you are not a energy focused student, this course may not be for you. it is very specific and some students may find it boring.
Readings are pretty important to see how some of the lecture material fits into the bigger picture. Problem sets are fun, but can take a good amount of time.
If you're interested in energy, you have to take this course.
Take it.
take it! take a nap before because 3 hour classes in the evening are brutal. also, don't bring your laptop and email the whole time. that's rude, and it's a waste of your time.
Great if you want to learn about the electric utility space. First lectures are the most important ones for that. The later ones sort of go off topic a little bit.

If you are interested in energy, particularly the electric and natural gas monopolies, take this course. And while the utilities are largely US-based, there is still a significant amount of crossover to other countries.
Make sure to cover the readings!
NA
